Award.AwardTitle: Field-theoretic simulations with excluded volume correlations
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nontechnical Summary
This award supports development of a theoretical and computational framework for understanding the thermodynamics of polymer nanocomposites, a class of materials where small, typically inorganic nanoparticles are dispersed in a polymer matrix. Polymer nanocomposites are explored for a diverse set of applications ranging from lightweight protective materials to plastic membranes with tunable electronic properties, yet there are relatively few modeling techniques capable of accurately predicting their equilibrium structure and properties. This research will help with development of a family of new modeling techniques capable of predicting how polymer nanocomposites will assemble on the molecular level. This could aid in the design of conductive plastic materials, polymers with tunable optical properties, and mechanically robust polymer nanocomposites.

This award will support training of graduate students in molecular modeling techniques and modern polymer science. The students will interact with experimental groups in Chemistry, Materials Science, and Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering Departments at the University of Pennsylvania. The developed simulation codes will be made publicly available. This will facilitate the broader application of new modeling techniques.

Technical Summary
This award supports the development of field theoretic simulation framework for a class of problems where excluded volume correlations become important. In traditional implementations of polymer field theory, the constituents of the model are taken as either point particles or infinitely thin threads with a contact repulsion. However, in a number of technologically important materials ranging from polymer nanocomposites to polyelectrolytes exposed to multivalent ions, a point-particle description is invalid. The goal of this funded research is to extend the field theoretic simulations framework to study: (i) the distribution of both spherical and anisotropic nanoparticles in a polymer matrix, including phase separated polymer blends and block copolymers; (ii) homogeneously grafted nanoparticles, where the grafting sites are uniformly distributed on the nanoparticle surface; and (iii) charged polymeric systems in the presence of multivalent ions. The results the field theoretical calculations will be compared with particle-based simulations and with existing experiments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Polymer nanocomposites are a promising class of materials because by their very nature they combine materials that typically have complementary properties. Polymers provide a lightweight and mechanically robust matrix to host nanoparticles that often have interesting electrical and optical properties. It has been demonstrated in many experiments that the structure of these composites plays a significant role in their resulting properties, but anticipating the structure is a significant challenge because their thermodynamics were poorly understood. The research goal and intellectual merit of our project was to develop mesoscale simulation methods that enable the prediction of the thermodynamics and structure of polymer nanocomposites by rigorously extending a theoretical tool commonly used for polymers to also include nanoparticles. Our framework can be treated numerically or approximated analytically, and it enables the study of systems that are beyond that which can be treated using traditional molecular simulations. The framework we have employed to develop the methods has been field theoretic simulations, which are commonly used for inhomogeneous polymer melts and blends, but traditionally do not allow for excluded-volume type interactions that are necessary to describe how a nanoparticle will affect the conformations available to a polymer chain. We have demonstrated that excluded volume interactions can be incorporated into the field theory framework in a natural and computationally efficient way, and it has enabled our research on polymer nanocomposites. Our focus has been on the development of the method, though we have also developed collaborations with experimental research groups to test our models more precisely. Finally, the inclusion of excluded volume interactions into a field theory also has broader implications for other soft matter systems, such as polyelectrolytes in the presence of multivalent counterions, which are ubiquitous in biological systems. We have demonstrated that our approach captures many of the qualitative phenomena observed in simulations and experiments expected for polyelectrolytes near multivalent ions. The broader impacts of our work has included the education of undergraduate and graduate scientists, and this work has resulted in publications with undergraduate authors. Furthermore, this research has piqued the interest of industry in the Philadelphia area as chemical companies become increasingly interested in polymer nanocomposite materials. The methods developed under this award have led to two industry-sponsored research projects, one with DuPont (before their merger with Dow), and an ongoing project with ExxonMobil.
